• Difficulty eliciting key ideas from students

sec.title: Keeping a Focus on Meaning
sec.p: The last task of steering instruction toward the mathematical point that I identified in these data is keeping a focus on meaning. Because the ultimate goal of mathematics instruction is to develop mathematical proficiency, which intertwines conceptual understanding and reasoning with procedural fluency, mathematics instruction needs to help students attend to mathematical meaning (Hiebert & Grouws, 2007; National Research Council, 2001). Although there is some overlap between keeping a focus on meaning and some of the other tasks identified (in particular, with opening up and emphasizing key mathematical ideas), these tasks are not the same. For example, emphasizing a key idea does not require a focus on meaning (e.g., the idea being emphasized could be about developing skills or a more efficient procedure), and a teacher can focus on meaning even when an idea is not being emphasized (e.g., by using conceptual language or quickly defining a new term).

Written records and representations are a key component of mathematics teaching and learning (Ball, 1993; Ball & Bass, 2003) and can be used to keep a focus on meaning. Courtney’s second-grade lesson provided many examples of deploying representations to focus on meaning. For example, when modeling a problem using multiple representations, she lined up the components of her diagrams to make more visible the correspondences between them and then used this to highlight their mathematical meaning.

One issue that can arise when using records and representations to focus on meaning is when students cannot see what is displayed. This happened in Mia’s lesson on graphing. To emphasize the importance of reading a graph’s labels, she designed an activity in which students compared two bar graphs with identical shapes but different labels. However, because she used the overhead projector, she was unable to display the graphs simultaneously. This made it difficult for students to compare the graphs and thus detracted from her mathematical point.

Another issue that can occur is that what is recorded inadvertently obscures or confuses the mathematics. For example, in her lesson on decimals, Nicole tried to emphasize the names of the places by recording them on the whiteboard. Because she wanted to highlight the –th sound in “tenths” (N-Post, T115-124), she labeled the tenths column with “Th.” In this case, Nicole’s use of recording to emphasize the –th sound may have confused students because “Th” is often used to label the thousands place. Thus, when making records to emphasize a particular idea, it is also important to consider the potential impact of the recording on its conveyance of meaning.

Another issue that can arise is inherent in using representations: Students might attend to mathematically irrelevant features of the representation (Nolder, 1991; Sierpinska, 1994). One way teachers can manage this is by being explicit about what students are supposed to attend to (and not attend to) in a given representation. For example, as Courtney was drawing little lines to model the numbers in a comparison problem, one of her students commented that she needed to use a slash to group five tallies. Courtney acknowledged this confusion by clarifying, “I’m not doing tallies I’m just doing little marks.” Whether this resolved the issue and steered the student toward the intended mathematical point is unknown, and it could be argued that it would have been clearer to use another representation (e.g., small dots); however, this example illustrates the importance of not assuming students are attending to the intended mathematical meaning.

A related issue that can arise when using representations to focus on meaning is that the referent is unclear to students. Unclear referents can cause confusion and obfuscate intended meaning (Rowland, 1999; Sierpinska, 1994). For instance, in Rachel’s lesson, when she asked students to name fractions of a folded square, it was often unclear to which portion of the square she was referring. Similarly, in Irene’s fact families lesson, she covered one side of the domino and then asked students what was taken away, hiding the number to which she was referring.

Another strategy teachers can employ to keep a focus on meaning is to use “meaning-focused language.” One type of meaning-focused language is saying “full names”—that is, not taking shortcuts with language when naming mathematical objects or definitions. For example, Courtney used full names when referring to components of the diagram she was using for comparison problems (e.g., saying “bigger quantity box” rather than “the big one” or simply pointing). When the mathematical point of a lesson is to develop procedural fluency, meaning-focused language can help keep concepts in play, enabling simultaneous work across strands of mathematical proficiency. For example, the purpose of Andrea’s fifth-grade lesson was to develop procedural fluency with the long division algorithm. Although her lesson was not focused on decimals, she read 87.6 as “eighty-seven and six-tenths” rather than “eighty-seven point six,” language that makes more visible the underlying place value structure and connection to fractions.

Teachers can miss opportunities to use meaning-focused language to engage students with the intended mathematics, and in some cases, not using meaning-focused language can interfere with steering an activity toward its mathematical point. For example, in her third-grade lesson on decimals, Nicole rarely read fractions and decimals using the language of “tenths” and “hundredths” (e.g., she read
16
100
and .16 as “sixteen out of a hundred” rather than “sixteen-hundredths”), which was problematic because place value with decimals was the lesson’s focal topic (contrast this with Andrea’s lesson on division that happened to use decimals).

Not using meaning-focused language can also distort the mathematical point. For example, in her graphing lesson, Beth repeatedly characterized the activity as “changing our information from our table to our graph.” While such statements may not have interfered with student learning, it is not true that the data changed; they were just represented differently. When students use imprecise language, the task of keeping a focus on meaning becomes even more complicated. One strategy is to offer a quick correction without taking up the imprecision. For example, when a student in Jordan’s class started explaining how to calculate 8 – (–4) by saying “there’s two negatives and that’s not possible,” Jordan quickly commented, “Well it’s possible, but it’s just, we want to think about it a different way,” and the student continued his explanation. In this case, Jordan did not dwell, but she did not allow the student’s mathematically imprecise statement to stand untroubled.

Another strategy for keeping a focus on meaning is to explicitly connect the activity back to the intended mathematics. For example, a teacher can connect student responses back to the problem being solved. Courtney made this type of move throughout her discussion of comparison problems. For instance, when a student correctly answered “eight” to one of her questions, she connected this back to what the problem was asking: “Eight is the smaller quantity. And we’re trying to find the difference.” When such connections are not made, the mathematical reasons for doing an activity can be unclear. In Courtney’s case, the teacher did the connecting; however, teachers can also support students in making these connections themselves.
Table 8 summarizes the task of keeping a focus on meaning.

tr.td: Strategies for Keeping a Focus on Meaning:
• Deploying representations in ways that highlight intended meaning
○ Being explicit about which features of a representation students are supposed to attend to (and not attend to)
○ Displaying representations in ways that make correspondences more visible
○ Making correspondences between representations explicit
○ Using meaning-focused language
○ Saying “full names”
○ Using conceptual language (even when the focus is on procedures)
• Explicitly connecting the activity to the intended mathematics
○ Connecting the answer back to what the problem is asking

td.italic: In addition, many strategies that are useful for emphasizing and opening up key mathematical ideas and for developing and maintaining a mathematical storyline also can help keep a focus on meaning (e.g., being explicit and “dwelling” in strategic places; framing, narrating, and summarizing the mathematical work; etc.).

tr.td: Problematic Issues That Can Arise:
• Deploying representations and records that students cannot see
• What is recorded distorts, obscures, or confuses the intended mathematics
• Students attending to irrelevant features of representations
• Unclear referents when deploying representations
• Not capitalizing on opportunities to use meaning-focused language
• Using language that distorts or detracts from the mathematical point
• Not noticing students’ use of mathematically imprecise language
• Mathematical reasons for engaging in an activity are unclear

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Steering instruction toward the mathematical point is crucial for teaching that supports the development of students’ mathematical proficiency. Inability to skillfully steer instruction risks wasted time, unproductive confusion, incoherent instruction, and superficial mathematical work—all conditions that can hinder students’ progress toward the intended learning goals. Yet simply stating that teachers need to steer instruction toward the mathematical point does not identify what is involved in doing this work. Needed are decompositions of practice that articulate and break apart key components of the work so they can be taught to and practiced by beginners (Grossman et al., 2009). During instruction, these components are integrated—and such recomposition is also the ultimate goal in teacher education—however, to support beginners in learning how to enact the whole it is necessary to articulate its parts. This study made a first step in decomposing the work of steering instruction toward the mathematical point by identifying its central tasks, strategies that can be used to enact those tasks, and issues that can arise when trying to do so.

Although there are other frameworks and observation protocols in the field that also decompose aspects of the work of teaching (e.g., Danielson, 2007; Junker et al., 2006), none focus on articulating the work of steering instruction toward the mathematical point. Furthermore, although aspects of the work of steering instruction can be inferred from other frameworks, other frameworks and observation protocols often focus exclusively on describing qualities of the teaching or student engagement, not on articulating what the work of teaching is. Or, in cases when the work of teaching is identified (or can be inferred), it is not decomposed at a grain size that is fine enough to be able to directly use the framework to teach beginners what to do. Thus, a major contribution of this study is an articulation of a key aspect of the work of teaching at a grain size that is directly usable in the design of practice-based teacher education.

In addition to identifying practices that beginning teachers need to learn, results from this study can be used to develop tools to support preservice teachers’ learning in and from practice (Lampert, 2010). Such tools could be used in teacher education courses to study records of practice, support preservice teachers’ reflection on their own teaching, or assist field instructors when debriefing observed lessons. For instance, a lesson planning tool might prompt preservice teachers to identify places to dwell on the mathematical point or to analyze whether selected numbers are likely to engage students with the intended mathematics; an observation/debriefing tool might help field instructors or mentor teachers observe preservice teachers’ lessons for the tasks of steering instruction and then facilitate conversation about the strategies used and issues that arose during the lesson. Case studies could be developed around the tasks of steering instruction to help preservice teachers identify strategies that can be used to productively steer instruction and issues that can arise that cause a lesson to get off track. Creating such tools would require additional development and validation work, but this study helps move the field in this direction.

Findings from this study can also be used as a lens for research on teaching, revealing aspects of practice that might be missed with other lenses. For example, even when a preservice teacher’s enactment seems to steer an activity in an unproductive mathematical direction, using the tasks of steering instruction as a lens can help illuminate productive instincts and sensibilities. For instance, although Nicole’s recording of “Th” for “tenth” in her decimal lesson was potentially confusing mathematically, her use of recording to emphasize a key mathematical idea can be a productive teaching move. By naming these types of moves, this study helps observers of practice distinguish between the intent of a move and the way in which it is implemented. Findings from this study can also inform the design of educative curriculum materials (Davis & Krajcik, 2005) by providing insight into the types of supports curriculum designers might include to help teachers steer instruction toward the mathematical point.

The conceptualization of steering instruction toward the mathematical point developed in this study could also be extended to subjects other than mathematics. For example, in history instruction, one could conceive of “steering instruction toward the historical point.” Although the overall conceptualization of “steering instruction” seems readily extendable to other subject areas, further research is needed to examine more closely the analogous work and to identify specific tasks, strategies, and issues. If there are aspects of steering instruction that are similar across the teaching of different subjects, this would be a way to help identify which tasks and strategies are more “high leverage” (Ball, Sleep, Boerst, & Bass, 2009) for preservice elementary teachers. In other words, overlapping components would help identify aspects of the work of steering instruction that apply across subjects, which can be strategic sites for elementary teacher education because of the need to prepare beginners to teach all subjects in a limited amount of time. At the same time, while many of the tasks may be parallel, there may also be important subject-specific differences in implementation that would need to be identified.

This study has a number of limitations. First, although the sample was varied in important ways (e.g., grade level, MKT, lesson topic), there were similarities that likely influenced the characterization of the work of steering instruction toward the mathematical point. For example, all of the preservice teachers were in the same teacher education program and almost all lessons used the same mathematics curriculum. Thus, the findings are likely missing aspects of the work that were not visible in the settings observed or were not apparent in single lessons. Another set of limitations emerges from the methods of analysis. Research like this is necessarily interpretive, and the findings reflect only what I was able to “see” in the data. Whether the distinctions made prove useful will ultimately be determined by whether and how the ideas can be taken up and used in future research and teacher education. Lastly, this study does not take up questions such as: How can preservice teachers learn to steer instruction toward the mathematical point? Are teachers with stronger MKT more skilled at steering instruction? Does skill in steering instruction toward the mathematical point improve the mathematical quality of instruction and lead to increased student learning? Though this study takes an important initial step, these crucial questions remain unanswered and point to directions for future research on steering instruction toward the mathematical point.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Teacher education must prepare teachers with the knowledge and skills necessary to achieve the bold vision of mathematical proficiency set by current K-12 standards and curricula. Doing so requires a better articulation of the work of teaching. This study decomposed and specified a central aspect of mathematics teaching: the work of steering instruction toward the mathematical point. The tasks of steering instruction indentified in this study, along with strategies that can be used to enact these tasks and issues that can arise when trying to do so, can inform the design of teacher education, research on teaching and teacher education, and the design and study of educative curriculum materials.
